captions.text:
Hello, Internet. A lot of you sent me this
image making the rounds which concerns the

Mayan prediction that the world will end on
December 21, 2012. The claim is that the Mayan

calendar short counted the years because they
forgot about leap days so the world should

have already ended. This is followed by Mind
= Blown, which I'm not sure how to take. Do

people think that the world forgot to have
its apocalypse or that were it not for leap

days that we'd already be living in the future?
Either way, it's spawned many an argument

that people ask me to explain, which I'm happy
to do, because my next big video was delayed

by pestilence, which struck me down into the
depths of unproductive misery for the last

few weeks. So, if you haven't already, please
watch the related videos now as otherwise

this won't make a whole lot of sense and there
are a few corrections I'd like to make. The

first of these is that I shouldn't have called
the Mayans "Mayans". Maya is the correct singular

and plural noun to use in the same way that
sheep is both singular and plural. Mayan is

the name of the language and the adjective
form of the word as in the Mayan civilization.

Secondly, I showed a picture of the Aztec
calendar stone, rather than a Mayan calendar

in my 2012 video, which at the time I thought
was okay because the Aztec calendar is the

same as the Mayan, just with different names,
sort of like the Greek and Roman Gods. And,

frankly, the Aztec one is much cooler looking.
But I was still wrong to show it because despite

naming it the Aztec calendar stone, archeologists
don't actually think it's a calendar. And,

speaking of stone, I used the term Stone Age
to describe the Maya which made many people

very angry. For clarity, Stone Age does not
mean stupid, it's the technological classification

of a civilization limited to stone tools.
Advanced though their astronomy and mathematics

were, the Maya never discovered metallurgy
and thus couldn't move on to the Bronze Age

then the Iron Age then the Diamond Age. Right.
Enough corrections. It's explanation time

for this image which raised three questions:
1) Does the Mayan calendar have leap days?

2) Did the Maya miscount the years, 3) Should
the world have already ended? The answer to

all of these is, no. To briefly recap, leap
years exist to stop seasons from drifting

out of sync with the calendar, a problem that
vexed Pope Gregory because every year Easter

and spring were getting further apart. To
fix this, he introduced the modestly named

Gregorian calendar with its fancy leap year
rules to keep the seasons and thus the holidays

together. But, while Pope Gregory cared about
the seasons, the ancient Maya did not. Presumably

because where they lived the weather comes
in only one season, too hot and too humid.

So the Mayan calendar ignores seasons in favor
of accurately tracking the days since the

creation of the Mayan religion. This renders
leaps years an unnecessary complication. Though

the Mayan calendar is no stranger to complication
with its cycles within cycles within cycles

within cycles within cycles that, if you're
interested, Hank Green can tell you much more

about. But back to the miscounting claims
which comes from our idea that leap days are

extra days which, of course, they really aren't.
The Gregorian calendar doesn't give people

extra days any more than daylight saving time
gives people extra sunlight. If you transported

Pope Gregory 1,000 years back in time to meet
the Mayan Lady Xoc and then made them count

the days until this year's winter solstice,
they'd agree on that number because they're

just counting sunrises. It's not like Pope
Gregory with his clever modern calendar would

notice 500+ days that the Lady Xoc somehow
missed, perhaps while distracted by the pain

from her thorns through the tongue routine.
The only thing that they would disagree on

is what to call that day with Pope Gregory
insisting on December 21, 2012 and Lady Xoc

preferring the 13th Baktun. So, this image
is wrong because it's an apples to oranges

comparison. The Mayan calendar doesn't have
leap days because it doesn't need them. It

counts days just fine and its long cycle will
finish on December 21, 2012, but the world
will still go on.

title: Re: Leap Years, 2012 & The Mayan Calendar

comments.text:
Yeah you are not going to see this comment CGP Grey but I am going to make 
it anyway. If I remember correctly you said the ancient Maya were in the 
stone age in the original video to highlight the technological difference 
between us and them, right ? I think that is an unfair and misleading way 
to highlight the difference between us and them.

The three-age system has been criticized for its f.e. narrow focus and for 
being Eurocentric (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-age_system#Criticism). 
The societies of the world developed in different ways and when you try to 
classify non-Eurasian societies (societies in Africa and especially in the 
Americas and Australia) with the three age system you run into major 
problems. You are then putting f.e. the Mesoamerican civilization (for the 
most part, the Purépecha (see Tarascan state) people smelted copper 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pur%C3%A9pecha_people) in the same category as 
f.e. the early Stonehenge builders, while they were much closer to the 
bronze age and iron age societies of Eurasia in my opnion (not a 
historian)).﻿
comments.author: Olvirki

comments.text:
+Aconserva jones The term is far from being universally accepted, it a 
controversial term. I have to concede though that it can be used (but I 
guess I can criticize the use).

The term was invented to describe European societies (and the middle east 
?).
According to many scholars its not very helpful to describe some parts of 
the world (the term has even been called irrelevant for the Americas).

People didn't think he said they were stupid, they were criticizing the 
misleading use of the word (or I at least was).

comments.text:
The extra day in a leap year makes it so that the Gregorian calendar 
resolves itself every 4 x 365 days or a cycle of 4 years. Many ancient 
calendars did not add the extra day but still kept track so that they 
resolved every 4 x 365 YEARS or a cycle of 1460 years.﻿

comments.text:
Hello,

I've been watching some of your wonderful videos and got to the 2012/Mayan 
one in which you say that Pope Gregory (or strictly speaking his 
astronomers) added leap years to the calendar.  

The thing is, he didn't.  The Julian calendar had leap years every four 
years.  The Gregorian calendar dropped 10 days to get the calendar evened 
up with the seasons again and added the rule that century leap years would 
only occur if the century were divisible by 400.

Britain and the colonies didn't adopt this calendar until 1752, by which 
time the difference between Julian and Gregorian was 11 days, so they 
dropped 11 days out of September of that year, to the consternation of some 
people.

I belong to a church which uses the Julian calendar liturgically, and last 
century it was 13 days behind.  This century it's still 13 days behind 
instead of 14 because 2000 is divisible by 400.

comments.text:
Using 'stone-age' as a derisive term is what got people upset. Considering 
the other technological advances and a lack of necessity for metal tools I 
don't think the civilizations of the Americas fit so easily into our 
Stone/Bronze/Iron ages. Notice that in some parts of Africa the Iron age 
came before the Bronze due to different availabilities of metals 
(additionally Bronze age just means you have to alloy copper with something 
else; there are plenty of pure copper artifacts from their Stone age 
civilisation).

All the people way back then (and trust me, I was one of them) who said 
that the Mayan Calendar didn't account for Leap Years didn't even know how 
the calendar was recorded. In short, December 21st 2012 lined up with 
13.0.0.0.0 on the Mayan Calendar, more commonly referred to as the 13th 
(14th?) Ba'ak'tun (sp?) by the Maya. Either way, it didn't NEED to account 
for Leap Years.﻿

comments.author: Schinshikss

comments.text:
Yes, but the Mayan Calendar never had a "year." They had cycles, which are 
different. The Maya didn't say "On December 21, 2012," they said "in *__* 
number of cycles," because they didn't have years. The way they delineated 
time was very different. You should check out that video that CGP 
recommends to learn about that. The only reason we know that the date 
correlates with December 21, 2012 is because modern people, after the 
Gregorian calendar was implemented, did the math and added up the number of 
days, and they found that the date, using our calendar, was Dec 21, 2012.
comments.author: NanookRubbedIt

The amount of days wouldn't change but the date would be different. without

and you are not quite getting it. You said "... no, a human-sacrificing, 
stone-age society with neither wheels to pull carts nor glass to make 
telescopes, didn’t know more about science at the dawn of history than real 
scientists do today." If you only related one technology to another, that 
would be fine, but you mention human sacrifices and thorn pulling as if 
they have anything to do with their desire or ability to engage in science. 
You were clearly insinuating that they were too irrational to engage in 
science. And again you used the term "real scientists", though I am unclear 
whether you were referring to the New Agers or the Maya. And finally "stone 
age" may technically refer to technology choices, but in practice it is 
used to apply a primitiveness to people, and one should be cognizant of a 
word's colloquial use as much or more than its technical or scientific use, 
since you are talking about people after all.  These misnomers are typical 
of dismissive racist Western and modern attitudes on non-Western and 
non-Modern peoples, and you need to be more aware of how you relate to 
different cultures and how these things come across.﻿
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
+nittyjee
You are demonstrably incorrect. CGP Grey clearly stated that they were a 
"society with neither wheels to pull carts nor glass to make telescopes". I 
would spot telescopes under "modern science".
comments.author: Monochromicornicopia

comments.text:
+Monochromicornicopia
CGP Grey never made the distinction between modern science and science at 
large. And I have repeatedly made that distinction, and its claim of 
monopoly over science.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
+GamingProjectMarley Yes, you are correct. That does not change the fact 
that people find the insinuations offensive now. Whether they were extinct 
or not, it uses the same rhetoric of cultural superiority of Western and 
Modern civilization in the present. And as I mentioned before: "the Maya 
are not extinct, there are 6 million ethnic Maya today, and claim roots 
with the "Mayan Civilization" as a continuity, just like ethnic Greeks do 
today despite also being railroaded and assimilated by Christian states."

I have a feeling that everyone here is of Western origin. You are both 
demonstrating and failing to understand how the rhetoric of cultural 
superiority is being repeated here, because you clearly have it deeply 
engrained in your minds and how you see the world.

I am going to disable comments now. I was hoping that I could get CGP 
Grey's attention, who is intelligent and willing to correct inaccuracies. 
Instead I got progressively less useful comments. Youtube does not curate 
discussions like places like reddit, I should never ever use this.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
Something tells me that an exctinct nation who will never ever be able to 
watch this video aren't going to care if someone says something about in a 
video.
comments.author: Leavon5

comments.text:
+nittyjee
Modern science, kid. *Modern* science.
comments.author: Monochromicornicopia

comments.text:
+Michael Henman "As for human sacrificers being incapable of science, it 
seems likely that if you believe that murdering people for some imaginary 
friend for material gain is acceptable or effective, then you are likely 
lacking in scientific understanding or willingness to engage in learning."
A willingness to engage in human sacrifice has nothing to do with your 
willingness to engage in learning, however systematic. Every one of the 
most developed scientific cultures in history has engaged in some sort of 
irrational behavior. In fact, war, imperialism and genocide under were 
accomplished more effectively with science in the modern era. If you 
believe that the Modern era was morally and rationally infallible, then you 
are, like the Mayans with human sacrifice, living a myth.
You mention 1000's of years - this contradicts your statements, as that 
goes back well before the modern era, to when Europeans were as "idiotic" 
as you mentioned. The fact that you are willing to mention 1000s of years 
of accumulated knowledge, which you are implying that Mayans did not have, 
and in fact every civilization had, makes me guess that you are referring 
to European people. The common narrative is "science started with Greeks, 
paused, then continued in the modern era." This is a racist and false 
narrative.
Also, I never in any way said or implied that they were as well informed as 
people today. You said that.
If you claim to believe in science, then look at science itself 
systematically. You will find that it is much more broad and deep than the 
common myths of Modernity claims. Definition of science: "the intellectual 
and practical activity encompassing the systematic study of the structure 
and behavior of the physical and natural world through observation and 
experiment." You cannot create a pyramid without science. Mayans had plenty 
of them. In fact, any technology requires science, even the most simple 
like clothing, cooking and pottery. It is as old as humanity itself. And 
every civilization had to have science to even exist as a civilization, 
which requires systematic understanding and knowledge. To the degree that 
there were dedicated scientists and active systematic study varied from 
place to place, and that is irrelevant. This monopoly on science by Western 
and Modern Civilization is based on a deep seated notion of cultural 
superiority of the Whites and the Modern culture that they originated. If 
you ask many people whether hunter-gatherers had science or Mayans had 
science, they laugh or get agitated, especially many Western philosophers 
and scientists, whose bestowal of priesthood would be undermined. Like 
them, I find that everyone here is simply stomping their feet and getting 
upset, because they don't like what I am saying, however reasonable it is. 
So far everyone has tried to get around what I am saying, rather than 
actually engaging the idea and looking within themselves to seeing where 
there could be something missing in the way you see the world and regard 
other cultures.

@Monochromicornicopia"... no, a human-sacrificing, stone-age society with 
neither wheels to pull carts nor glass to make telescopes, didn’t know more 
about science at the dawn of history than real scientists do today."
I do not see how you cannot see that he is insinuating that they are 
connected, when he mentions them in the same sentence, as if one has to do 
with the other. You'll have to explain this, maybe I am missing something.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
Real scientists: People who understand and use the scientific method, carry 
out reliable experiments, and record their results in modern scientific 
journals.
The Mayan's didn't have access to 1,000s of years of accumulated scientific 
knowledge from all over the world and modern equipment, but your comment 
seems to imply that they were as well informed as people today. And I don't 
consider it racist in any way to insult primitive cultures and non modern 
people. I am a white european, and fully acknowledge that my ancestors were 
a bunch of primitive war mongering idiots, that used leeches for medicine, 
considered slavery acceptable, and mostly wasted their lives bowing down to 
some great lord or other. The same could be said for any culture, it's not 
racist or narrow minded, just fact.
As for human sacrificers being incapable of science, it seems likely that 
if you believe that murdering people for some imaginary friend for material 
gain is acceptable or effective, then you are likely lacking in scientific 
understanding or willingness to engage in learning.
comments.author: Michael Henman

comments.text:
+nittyjee
"but it is not a fact that "human-sacrificing" and "pulling thorns through 
tongues" has anything to do with your ability or desire to conduct "real 
science"" - I never said it does. He wasn't insinuating anything of the 
sort. You're imagining racism.
comments.author: Monochromicornicopia

comments.text:
+Monochromicornicopia "... no, a human-sacrificing, stone-age society with 
neither wheels to pull carts nor glass to make telescopes, didn’t know more 
about science at the dawn of history than real scientists do today."
Yes, "human-sacrificing, stone-age society with neither wheels to pull 
carts nor glass to make telescopes" and "didn’t know more about science at 
the dawn of history" are factual statements, but it is not a fact that 
"human-sacrificing" and "pulling thorns through tongues" has anything to do 
with your ability or desire to conduct "real science", which he was clearly 
conflating and insinuating. Please focus on what I am trying to say, and 
address it directly.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
+AzathothLives
He was not being racist. He was making a purely factual statement. This 
specific group of people were a human-sacrificing, stone-age society with 
neither wheels to pull carts nor glass to make telescopes, didn’t know more 
about science at the dawn of history than real scientists do today. How is 
that racist? These are objectively true statements.
comments.author: Monochromicornicopia

comments.text:
+nittyjee So your upset that he made what is essentially a racist joke at 
the Mayan's expense. I can understand what you mean and why your offended 
by it, but... I'm not. It wasn't done in malice.

He admits they were an advanced society in mathematics and astronomy, but 
you shouldn't look towards them for future predictions. Maybe he should not 
have made light of them, but flipping out isn't the right response either. 
And is missing the point of his video entirely for the sake of 
contentiousness. 

Get a sense of humor and some thicker skin? I don't mind when people make 
jokes about my religion. I'll be the first to admit they did some horrible 
things in the past.

But that was the past. Most cultures got up to barbaric practices in the 
past. And the few that didn't usually got rolled over by the majority that 
did. Its not like we are perfect and peaceful in the modern age (Middle 
East and Africa), but its certainly better than the past.
comments.author: AzathothLives

comments.text:
+AzathothLives Finally, someone who is focusing on the point, thank you. I 
am not attacking anyone's character.  I can see how people would think that 
I am, because writing does not convey tone. Perhaps I should have said that 
clearly before. It is extremely rare that no one has racial, gender, 
ethnic, class, etc. biases, including myself. I don't judge anyone for 
these biases personally, especially someone like CGP Grey. Just the other 
day a friend of mine pointed out that I was judging someone more for being 
a woman, and I agreed with her 100%. These are things we all need to work 
on.
Yes, I do think that he did insinuate that "... They cant know anything 
about astronomy, because they were too busy sacrificing humans..." among 
other things. I don't see how the following sentence does not insinuate 
that. You essentially rewrote a part of it:
"... no, a human-sacrificing, stone-age society with neither wheels to pull 
carts nor glass to make telescopes, didn’t know more about science at the 
dawn of history than real scientists do today."
You got it. And the part of the quote that said "real scientists", as if 
science is a monopoly of Modern civilization and institutions. This is 
biased, yes. This rhetoric of "look at these people, they are so 
irrational, look at the things they do"... is used to denigrate people 
everywhere outside the modern or Western world.
I am aware that probably 95% or more of the science ever conducted has been 
done by modern scientists, but that does not mean that everyone else was 
too consumed in being irrational to not engage in what we do. There had 
neither the technology nor the sheer numbers we do today. That is besides 
the point.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
So your saying CGP (and me, despite you not knowing anything about me) 
discredits Mayan science because of racial and cultural bias. One of those 
logical fallacies where you attack the character of a person instead of 
their argument.

Basically "Those Mayans. They cant know anything about astronomy, because 
they were too busy sacrificing humans and not building wheels." I see your 
point, but lets be clear about something. This is the modern age, we have 
very intelligent people building off of vast libraries of knowledge that 
our ancestors could only dream of.

Do we know everything about everything? No. And unfortunately there are 
some things that have been lost in the past which we need to rediscover. 
History was a rough and uncaring place. And anything not carved in stone or 
locked in a monastery has been lost.

Also I am a firm believer that humans have been incredibly intelligent for 
thousands of years. We are good problem solvers. And the testaments to that 
still stand. Both in the mega projects we made from stone and in remnants 
of clockwork devices found in shipwrecks.

That all said, CGP's point is, which I note you missed, that scientists of 
today have access to tools and knowledge that no other society has EVER had 
access to. We know more about our world, our universe, and ourselves than 
ever before, and it makes sense to trust the judgments of current 
generation scientist over that of ones from thousands of years ago.
comments.author: AzathothLives

comments.text:
+nittyjee
The quote that you just used is completely true in every objective way. You 
can't dispute that statement as anything other than factual.
comments.author: Monochromicornicopia

comments.text:
+Monochromicornicopia No. The "irrational attributes" are not what he is 
explaining, as if they are equal, and we are all irrational. He is 
comparing us to them, and claiming that we are more rational than them, and 
they are too irrational to engage in scientific thought.
Quote:
"... no, a human-sacrificing, stone-age society with neither wheels to pull 
carts nor glass to make telescopes, didn’t know more about science at the 
dawn of history than real scientists do today.
... along with the point I made following it above.

Again, please address the specific quotes and points I am making.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
Every culture has irrational attributes. Why are you complaining about CGP 
Grey describing the irrational attributes of the Maya?
comments.author: Monochromicornicopia

comments.text: You got it, chief.

comments.text: +QuarterMOA890 see note above
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text:
+AzathothLives +QuarterMOA890 Normally I wouldn't bother commenting on a 
video, because youtube is a fetid wasteland of belligerence, but CGP Grey 
is an intelligent person, and cared to spend hours making quality, detailed 
videos and even made this one which corrected some earlier mistakes. His 
videos are in fact about *being* PC, defining something accurately and 
precisely. If you did in fact enjoy this video, my comments are in fact 
helping, because it is specifically about correcting mistakes, and I was 
building on that. If you are concerned about PC-ness wasting your time, you 
should not watch this video - "Maya" vs. "Mayan" for example is far more 
"frivolous" than my statements. And to respond to an actual assertion, 
QuarterMOA890, the Maya are not extinct, there are 6 million ethnic Maya 
today, and claim roots with the "Mayan Civilization" as a continuity, just 
like ethnic Greeks do today despite also being railroaded and assimilated 
by Christian states. If this video were in Spanish, many people would have 
been deeply offended, but it speaks primarily to certain English-speaking 
audiences. People would have been offended if he insinuated the same 
cultural superiority over Native Americans, which the Maya technically are, 
outside the US. It is common that Americans relate to racism as purely our 
personal societal experience as if it exists in a vacuum, without a wider 
context and a wider mindset and rhetoric.
I respect CGP Grey, but it appears that he and you have no appreciation and 
in fact embody the the systemic biases and condescending attitudes about 
"immoral" and "irrational" and "inferior" non-Christians, non-Whites and 
non-Westerners. It is completely over your heads and you completely miss 
the point. Regardless of being extinct or alive, CGP Grey's comments were 
clearly offensive. No one has yet addressed my comments, only jumped up and 
down and said "I don't like you." So like CGP Grey, provide actual 
intelligent responses to what I have said, rather than being sensitive 
about me being sensitive or uptight about me not being relaxed, or from 
here on I will likely disregard it, and if you feel it is frivolous, then 
likewise ignore it rather than wasting both of our time.
comments.author: nittyjee

comments.text: You need to relax. Your defense of an extinct people is laughable.
comments.author: QuarterMOA890

comments.text:
The supposed "end" of the Mayan long count calendar, 13.0.0.0.0 is simply a 
specific number of days (1,872,000) from the beginning of the calendar, 
0.0.0.0.0. When Europeans discovered this calendar, they translated the 
Mayan date to a Gregorian date of December 21, 2012, taking into account 
all the conventions and quirks of the Gregorian/Julian system, including 
leap years and the lack of a year zero. So no, will not be 12-21-2013.
comments.author: Spandy Yaroch
